commentBody: I enjoyed this relatively meaty Tuesday.  I wasn’t very far into when I found it had “groan” on me.

The Balaam clue, if you're familiar with your Bible stories, is worth the price of admission here.  It's 21A, and I dare not write the answer, lest the 60D's decide to give me a hard time.

!!!

!!!

I just submitted my comment about the Balaam clue, and Marshall's comment preceded me by a few minutes, and so I refreshed the page.  Marshall's and my comments were both there.

And the heading at the top said:

Comments  1

And that, my friends, is the NYT comment system, in a nutshell.
The SW took me as long as the rest of the puzzle, found that corner to be late-week difficulty.
Great job, Justin!  Glad the puzzle was finally accepted. Thoroughly enjoyed it,  punny humor and all!

60D is a bird often discussed here, but this is my first sighting in the wild.

The link to this column from the iPad app seems broken today, or maybe it’s just me.

The power of persistent puzzling; last week's Natick is this week's gimme. My first entry in the SW, helping to crack that corner and make it first to fall https://www.newyorker.com/puzzles-and-games-dept/crossword/2024/10/07
Tuesday's puzzle was uncharacteristically difficult for a Tuesday, however, that only made it that much more enjoyable to solve. Fantastic job, Justin!

Fun puzzle, cute theme, even for those who don't eat meat.  "Go over the line" was a great clue; original?  I was happy to get Aegis right away.

The constructor note was charming.  Good stuff.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

WHAT A BOAR that southwest corner was. I had the rest of the puzzle near finished in with under 7 minutes and then I hit that tiny section. I found it to be Fridayish difficulty. Finished around 20 minutes. On a Tuesday! Woo doggy.

And, as I always say, I’ll take too tough over too easy *any day of the week*.  I love Tuesdays with *a little gristle*. 

I thought the theme was really great and enjoyed the whole puzzle. Thanks, Justin Werfel!

I can’t wait to see a bunch of GAUCHE 21As DIS the answer to 20A because they don’t understand that part of the purpose of moderated comments is to provide AEGIS for all those who SOLVE and who would, AT A GUESS, prefer to STOOP to commenting on what has become of Twitter.

Today (Oct 7 at night) when I click on the link to go to Wordplay l get a page which says "Not Found". 

Can we get refunds for times when the service is unavailable?

Tried to do this one with the Downs only….just couldn’t finish it. But it made for some fun discovery of the theme clues, which we did get. Didn’t feel as satisfying an experience since we were not looking at half the constructor’s work—that seemed rude?

I got beef with this one! Poultry clues, pesce answers! Butchered puns! A veal chore to solve!




cc: emu handler
Glad I got “on me” because I definitely wouldn’t have known that goat noise.

Got to the end, got told I had at least one square wrong, wondered if it was the 11D/28A cross that was the last square I filled since I didn't recognize TABOR, but couldn't figure out what else could fill MADE _ACK. Confirmed TABOR fit the 28A clue, couldn't figure out where else my error could be, thought it might be EApE in 56D but thought the error was in the first square even though I didn't know what else could complete GAUCH_. Ran the autocheck for the first time ever on a Tuesday puzzle... and it was the 58D/67A cross I got wrong, even though 67A was covered in the column. I think I got misled by the column saying the two words were similar, so even though I'd just read it, after filling APIAN on 14A I naturally drifted to ApIARY on 67A and didn't bother to wonder if it was right until the end because "it was in the column, therefore I already know it's right!" 🤦‍♂️

I laughed at the WURST thing - my wife and I often use that wurst/worst play-on-words when mixing German and English into our private language, which is mostly Polish, but possibly would not be recognized as such by anybody else but us.

I got the theme, mostly, which is not a given when phonetics are involved. Is "what a bore" a quote from Charlotte's Web? In this clue all I understand is bore and BOAR sounding the same (or was it not bore at all, but some other word?), but everything else is a mystery.

The SW corner was very hard for me today, possibly even the WURST.  AEGIS was a gimme, RES came to me quickly, even though it is not used in Polish legalese (I may be a lawyer btw, but I am also a huge hater of legalese), and I somehow remembered GAUCHE, with crosses, but I needed to look up GRE and do some mental gymnastics to finish that part of the puzzle. I managed in the end, which I am somewhat proud of. My solve time was closer to Wednesday levels though, which has become quite common on Tuesdays in the past few months. My Tuesday PB is 7ish minutes, and lately I've been doing Tuesday puzzles in 12-14ish minutes.

I still don't get "Tee preceder:ESS". Esstee? ST? The only STs I know are: 1. a line of fast-ish Fords, 2. gamer shorthand for single target damage (rather than AoE, area of effect). I would appreciate an explanation :)

Be a dear and skip the venison. 

What an amusing theme and revealer. All based on very common phrases, yet amazingly each is a debut entry. That’s impressive. 

Thanks, Justin. That was fun!
Medium difficulty but rare cleverness.  Well done!
This page's URL is missing "2024-" before "10-8.html".

Too funny!  MAKE ENDS MEAT made me laugh out loud.  All of the themers were excellent, especially ON THE LAMB.  [Building with many wings?] for AVIARY is crossword gold.  The SW made me think on a Tuesday.  Great puzzle, Justin.

Tough one for a Tuesday, but finally tumbled to the trick and worked it all out. Pretty clever idea. Very amusing puzzle find today - a Sunday from May 7, 2007 by Patrick Berry with the title "Dinner theater." Some theme answers in that one: BAREFOOTINTHEPORK THEMERCHANTOFVENISON WUSTSIDESTORY PORGYANDBISQUE ABIESIRISHROAST And some others. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/27/2007&g=59&d=A I'm done. ..

Chewy, meaty Tuesday!

I liked it!

And absolutely love that you proposed with 
a crossword puzzle.

Tremendously cool and nerdy move.
I like your style.

Any puzzle referencing Howard ASHMAN is okay by me.
And let's hear it for Toughened Up Tuesdays.
Loved it!

The fish and the rabbit called: they say they are perfectly ok with having missed the cut.

Not the safest of solves, but at least the LAYERS didn’t end up as broilers.

Fun and fulfilling.

A smooth solve except for the SW with the, as least to me, awkward AT AGUESS instead of AsAGUESS, a shield name and the TIL, RES.   But got it worked out soon enough in this funny (punny?) sojourn.  

I was going to BBQ during the storm but I did not want to brisket.  

Many thanks.
The link to this page form the app is broken

A good challenge for a Tuesday. I was cruising until I hit the south when I ran into quite a few snags…but I enjoyed it, since I’d rather have a more difficult crossword than an easy one. I also appreciate the puns…FEAR THE WURST actually made me laugh aloud. 

One small, well, not a nit but a question…did anyone else get stuck briefly by 1A, “Tackle, as a crossword”? I don’t consider attempting the crossword as a SOLVE until, well, I solve it and get the star and the tiny tune of triumph. As I say, this is quite small as I enjoyed this CW quite a bit.

In trying to guess the revealer without reading the revealer clue, I got the whole thing bass-ackwards.  Since the original phrase didn't end in a real meat and the meat was a substitute for the real word, I was thinking of one of these ghastly substitutes made with some sort of awful soy product.  But what?

MEAT SUBSTITUTES?  Too long.  IMITATION MEAT?  SOY-BASED MEAT? ERSATZ MEAT?  I gave up.

I was on the wrong track -- and I smiled broadly when MAKE ENDS MEAT came in.  "That's nice -- that's very, very nice," I thought.

I got all the theme answers with no more than two letters -- the clues were both easy and fair -- with the exception of WHAT A BOAR.  But while the themed part of the puzzle was easy, there were other clues I found puzzling.   I should know that two up quarks and a down quark = a PROTON?  Well, actually, probably I should -- but I didn't.

And what's a "bouncy castle" that's filled with AIR?  A balloon?

Oh so that's the derivation of AEGIS (as in under the aegis of).  I didn't know that!  It's very interesting and I feel more protected already.

And there are just about no names!!!!!  What a splendid Tuesday puzzle!
Okay, the Balaam one made me laugh out loud.
This was perfect for a Carnivore like me. STEAK. Yum. LAMB. Yum yum. Good job I’ve eaten today. 45A made me chuckle. I must be feeling a little better (she said, in between coughing bouts).
Enjoying the puns in the comments as much as the puzzle! Thanks, everyone. I'd try to come up with my own, but I don't want to ham it up.

I had to sleep on this one, I was stuck in the southwest last night, but filled it in in a flash this morning, I shouldn't be surprised but was.
What a fun puzzle, lots of clues on the outer periphery of my knowledge. Loved the themers, even the gamy one.
Throwing the flag on “at a guess”. Otherwise fantastic.

I had saunter before SWAGGER and that threw off my SW for a while, until I filled in the WHAT of WHATABOAR. Suddenly, I was able to finish the corner speedily and was rewarded with the happy music. 

Sometimes it's really hard to let go of the absolutely wrong answer, isn't it?

SASSASSASSET(putting them together so as not to run afoul of you know who)

And ASHMAN is almost Kramer's license plate.

Loved the revealer!

B
O
W
S
T
ON THE LAMB

Is that a meat and greet?

I’m rarely disappointed in the NYT Games universe, but it’s a very special day when the crossword, the Wordplay column, and the constructor notes are all equally satisfying, clever, and delightful. Add a fabulously fun, completely unexpected column photo and the whole program leaves an afterglow that makes me very grateful for all the effort required to put it all together and get it so right. (If anyone thinks this is easy, think again.)

Sam, Justin, and the games crew knocked it out of the park today. I was too late to comment yesterday, but the Monday puzzle experience was exceptional, too. What a week so far!
A difficult Tuesday! Fun puns.
Go over the line? is SUCH a good clue! When it clicked, I nearly applauded in my cubicle
I never sausage a sinewy Tuesday, but I chewed through it thoroughly and only googled ASHMAN to make sure that was right. Audrey II would surely have appreciated such a fleshy puzzle.

To Justin Werfel:

Loved your Constructor notes!
Love hearing romantic stories about proposals; DHubby isn't that sort, but oh well....he had other qualities.  One thing of note:  do men with last names beginning with W realize how much we ladies are impacted when we give up our place in line?  I went from being in the H's to being waaaaay down in the W's (with an Americanized Swiss-German name.)

This puzzle had a personal touch for me, as my late father worked on both the Mars ROVERS and the AEGIS guided missile system. (High-tech cable connector design, not the rocket science.)

Loved the tasty puns. Are there British bacon shows? If not, there should be.
This is the first NYT crossword that had me laughing out loud at several clues/answers. I certainly hope Justin Werfel will submit more crosswords and that NYT editors will accept them.
Fun puzzle. The linguist in me has to be a d bag for a sec though and mention that "mer contents" is leading you to a plural but the answer is singular...

I loved this puzzle! Loved it! What a perfect way to start a Tuesday.  
Thank you, Justin.  More please.

Clever puns!
Great clues!
Lots of laughs!
EMUS! 

Today's SOLVE was quite a TREAT.

A bit tough for a Tuesday, but I absolutely loved those long entries with the delightful puns. 

I was so pleased to finally get to the comments, and am still  worried that I might have messed things up trying.
Holy moly, I only needed two clues! Getting closer to solving more than a Monday puzzle on my own 😄
This was tough for a Tuesday but I LOVED the puns! Loved them so much I sent the bit to people over text after I finished. Well done!

To quibble - if it's nearly half the poem is it really the end of a sonnet? A couplet could be the end of a sonnet but the last 6 lines? 

I know what a Petrarchan sonnet is. I still stand by my point.

Loved the theme!!  Thanks for the challenging but fun Tuesday. 

Not a fan of the lipstick photo, however.  It just hits too close to home.

Wonderful puns.  I also enjoyed seeing BLAME followed by MEA culpa and APIARY followed by POSIES.  This was such fun.

Special wishes for safety go out to all those in Hurricane Milton's path.

With apologies - a late puzzle find, one of the strangest I've ever encountered. Anyway... a Sunday from October 3, 1971 by Alfio Micci with the title: "Arithmetricks." Some example theme clues and answers: Clue: 4 Answer: "SEVEN-THREE" Clue: 14 Answer: "THIRTEEN+ONE" Clue: 1/2 Answer: SIX/TWELVE And there were eleven theme answers in that one. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=10/3/1971&g=75&d=A ...
45 A. Took me waaaay back, to 7th grade that is. My teacher, at the end of class for days on end, read us Charlotte's Web. Believe it or not, it was something we all looked forward to. Some pig!!
Ha ha, the emus made it into today's puzzle.

Well that was fun!! A little tougher of a Tuesday, I thought, or maybe I'm just slower today. Either way, really nice puzzle!!

The theme was terrific—each one really tickled my ribs! Especially FEARTHEWURST!

Still, my favorite has to be a non-theme entry: 21A! Poor Balaam! Too funny! 

Also, REHEARSE for "Go over the line?" is great!

I filled in AsAGUESS at 39D and didn't realize that made SEsA, which made no sense. I corrected it and got the happy music, but ATAGUESS didn't seem right to me....  A very quick Goog seems to agree with what's in the puzzle—AT. Who knew!? Probably a lot of you did... Oh well, an easy fix when I reexamined the cross.
It’s solvable but a tough one for Tuesday. 53A, 57A, 69A, 40D and some others are all tough clues for Tuesday.  Cute theme though :)

Hello Crossword Community! For several months, we’ve been quietly cooking up a new phrase guessing puzzle, Zorse, and we released a beta version this week. The catch? It’s only available in Canada (for now). You can learn more about our beta testing process by reading this FAQ put together by our customer care team: https://help.nytimes.com/hc/en-us/articles/24174502647444-Beta-Games/ For those of you located in Canada you can access the Zorse beta here: https://www.nytimes.com/games/zorse If you are not located in Canada stay tuned for future Zorse updates. Thank you and happy puzzling!

With apologies, late 15 letter answer that dawned on me: 

ANNAMARIAISLAND

My grandparents had a home there many years ago and we used to stay out there frequently on summer vacation. Not surprised that it's never been in a puzzle.

If you're wondering why that occurred to me, all I can say is... wait until tomorrow night, and I think you'll figure it out.

..
I was surprised to finish this and find that it wasn't my best Tuesday time - such a smooth solve!!

PORK would have impressed me more than BOAR.  I'll have to go look up ENBY. 

Otherwise nice puzzle.

Can anyone explain 'Mer contents' - EAU?

My last word of the puzzle and one that left me scratching my head.
This was a tough Tuesday puzzle!  I needed the hints to solve.

I forgot to mention in my earlier comment that I wondered if anyone else got a kick out of 10 down's clue for ESTATE? "Huge tract of land." https://youtu.be/CJWRhWlsD1g?si=4Jx4BvpWp_kQA_Gm Emus, run away, run away!

My kind of "punishment".  I loved this puzzle.  The puns were so much fun.  I enjoyed the solve so much!  Please more. Thank you Justin Werfel and NYT crossword team.  This was such a pleasure.
My favorite was "raise the steaks"., "on the lamb" was not far behind and "what a boar" was delightful! 

Cheers y'all. Have fun with this one! Stay safe Florida.  I'll be watching the news and keeping track of what we can do to help. Where to send aid, and how to give support. Prayers for a soft landing.
I’m admittedly not the best puzzler but this was MUCH harder than any Tuesday crossword I’ve seen before. Felt like a We/Th to me.
Simply too difficult for a Tuesday.

Justin,

It is a Tuesday, my dude. Who hurt you.

I was innocently finishing up today’s crossword at my favorite café when a PETA activist came by and dumped a bucket of fake blood on me. 

Maybe a non-vegan warning label on any future puzzles that contain animal products, hmmm?

Really cute and fun Tuesday puzzle, if a bit harder than average. Being a late commenter, most of my observations have already been made, but I don’t think I saw this: Did anybody else confidently put in “hangar” for 67A? It certainly would have fit in with the theme, coincidentally!

What a pun-filled delight! And a breeze, too. Usually I get them done the night before, but home renovations got in the way and the crossword had to wait until this evening. This was the perfect end to a busy day! Now I need to look up competitive punning!
I loved it!!!  Made me laugh. Excellent.
Who doesn't love a good pun? Fear the wurst is by far the best, but the whole puzzle had me smiling and chuckling. This is definitely one of my favourites in a while!
Ok, this one was fun! Although I did feel bad for the vegetarians....
Much too difficult for a Tuesday! Not fun!

This puzzle cracked me up all the way through and "make ends meat" was the best ending to all your terrific puns. I always say I love me a bad pun and this puzzle was just what I needed today. Thank you Justin Werfel for probably my most laugh-filled NYT puzzle ever.
A delightful romp. And I love the Xword proposal.
Can we stop with the negative cluing of 'gauche'? I know it's a dextronormative world but maybe we could move towards a more inclusive one ...

For me, very clever and very doable.

When I got the revealer, I had to smile. What a neat way to tie things up, better than butcher string.

...

Too bad there couldn't have been a cheese entry near or, better yet, crossing 17A. 

That would have been a Wurst-Käse scenario.
I genuinely hate puns, and genuinely hated this puzzle. Way to hard for a Tuesday.

@Marshall Walthew 

That's sinew one.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@Steve L 
That one made me laugh, and brought back memories of Sunday School.

.............................................
..............................

@Steve L 

PS  The first time I submitted the above comment, I then refreshed the page again, and it had not appeared yet.  So, it was my other comment (the one about Balaam) and Marshall's comment.

And the heading said:

Comments  3


smh

@Steve L 

And I see there's another self-congratulatory article about the forums and their moderation at the top of the Wordplay section.  I don't have the stomach to actually read through it, even though this one doesn't seem to be blocked for Games subscribers, which is a nice change of pace.  :)

One would imagine that a bit less chest beating and a modicum of policy and technical development might be in order, but who are we to question the Wisdom of Emus.  Alas.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)
@B Where do you see this article? I'm a subscriber, and I don't see it!

@Steve L 

As a former developer, I am in some sympathy with the developers of these sites insofar as keeping data in sync.

There's a real challenge in complex data systems in keeping the data both highly available and highly consistent.

There are tradeoffs.  Would you rather have had it say 

   Comments 2

but taken an additional three seconds to get to you?

This isn't an attack on you by any means--it's more a defense of a technical crew who is probably stretched to its limits.

@LGinDC Direct link is https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/30/crosswords/gameplay-forums.html Still haven't / won't read it. Fittingly enough I just had a post delayed 6-8 hours before it appeared above. /emus are a harsh mistress ____________________ Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade (I do this instead of emuing)

@N.E. Body 

There have been 575 sightings of the EMU in the NYT crossword, with an additional 225 sightings of EMUS in the plural.

The last EMU was sighted on Sept. 22, while the previous multiple sighting was on Aug. 29.  Altogether, there have already been 14 sightings in 2024.

That's why the EMU is the official bird of crossworld.

@Steve L 

PS There have been only 30 sightings of DOUG, and just one of LIMU, clued as a Hawaiian seaweed and not an insurance company.



!!!!

!!!!

@Steve L 
We have to throw some kind of Wordplay party when EMU(S) hits 1000.

N.E. Body,

Nine emu hours later, and my iPad and I had to take the dumbwaiter to get here.

@Bill in Yokohama 

Steve L’s references puzzled me, too. 

But it finally occurred to me that “Doug” is likely the name of the EMU mascot Liberty Mutual (LIMU, in Steve’s lexicon).

I don’t watch TV, but I gather that the Liberty Mutual ads are ubiquitous. (I’ve probably seen a few on YouTube.)

@Steve L 

I sorta maybe sometimes even slightly enjoy one of the ads (the actor is talented) but somehow, until your post, I had managed to keep the ad campaign and crosswording emus separate in my head.  :(

/the same company's dockside commercials, on the other hand, are uniformly awful and lacking in... well, everything
____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

Thanks for clearing that up, Eric and Steve L


Eric, speaking of YouTube and avoiding ads, I recently started a 2-month trial of YT with no ads, and it's a total game-changer, I think I'll probably end up paying for no ads when the trial ends.

@Striker 
To be clear, I don’t mean ‘BOAR’ as in being bored, but ‘BOAR’ as in the beast. I was anything but bored while working on it.

@Striker 
Must say, I found today’s “Connections” to be quite a BOAR, as well!

@Striker
I was good with all of SW, except the Natick at AEGI  and A_HMAN.  Didn't know either, so had to ask my friend Mr. Google.

@Michael 

And yet you found your way here.

@Eric Hougland Parsingp the URL, one does wonder how "they" managed to make a muddle of the dates in the link https://www.nytimes.com/2024/10/07/crosswords/daily-puzzle-10-08.html?searchResultPosition=7#commentsContainer Leap Year possibly?

@Eric Hougland I did a search for 'wordplay' which, of course, only shows results for 'GamePlay'. I selected one of the GamePlay results then clicked WordPlay, then selected the first item on that list.

Not exactly easy.

@Michael 

When the link is bad, I go to the NYT home page and look under Games. It takes a little longer and is much less convenient than the direct link from the app, but it’s not that big a problem.

@Michael 

Are you serious about the refund? NYT games cost me about 50 cents per week, so each day of all the games is worth what? 8 cents? How much of that is the crossword blog? As only an add-on to one of the many games, its monetary value - or rather of a single day of easy access to it - must be less than 1 cent. Transaction costs would be greater than the refund...

@Andrzej 

Americans are phenomenally cheap.

We can't get rid of a currency which costs more to produce than it's worth (the penny) because people are terrified that their grocery bills will be rounded up to the nearest nickel or dime.  Nothing inflames an Americans heart more than feeling like they've been swindled out of $0.45 a year.

We could also do quite well without the nickel or the dime. 

Ironically, our hysteria about being cheated has led us to being conned on a massive scale in 2016, and possibly 2024.

@Francis 
We (Canada) got rid of the penny in 2013 and don't miss it one bit. 

Electronic transactions still use it, but cash transactions are rounded up or down to the nearest 5 cents.   It probably averages out so you don't really lose money, and most of the cash transactions I did worked out in the customer's favor. 

Come on USA, join the penniless coalition!

(.....and I just made it sound bad, lol)

@Janine 

America is a paralyzed giant.

@Janine 

Try to get a population that thinks that the moon landing was faked, the earth is flat,  and 1x1 = 2 that rounding after getting rid of the penny would mostly balance out.

"Against stupidity, the Gods themselves contend in vain."
    --Friedrich Schiller

@Justin 

Goats say MAA, sheep say baa.  I've had long conversations with both, so you can trust me.

@Justin 
There are a number of things that are neglected when it comes to modern life...
     Lack of exposure to basic things (where your food comes from, how to move a heavy object, where to press to stop bleeding, when to call a halt because a task like making this list is too daunting...)  give me strength!  

But above all, I am sad for people who haven't watched a group of kids (the goatie kind)  playing 'king of the mountain" in the spring sunshine....
@Mean Old Lady @Nancy Well, at least maa is a lot easier than filling in whatever the fox says. Time to go sign up for goat yoga.

@Andrzej 

Think alphabet.  Tee refers to the letter T, so the preceder is the letter S or ESS, if spelled out.

@Andrzej In E.B. White's "Charlotte's Web," Charlotte the spider weaves a web reading "Some pig!" in order to save the pig from slaughter. (It's viewed as something of a miracle.) It's a lovely book, well known in the US. I won't tell you any more, in case you wish to have the pleasure of reading it.

@Andrzej 

E.M.U. filter is on a tear lately.  I was one of those who tried to address your boar question.  :(

Hasn't shown up yet.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@Andrzej Most of us in the United States are in awe of people who can casually use three languages to make plays on words... not to mention knowing the difference between a play on words and a pun. 

When I was in Spain I saw a woman finish a brief exchange with someone in German, then effortlessly switch to English when she turned to me. I asked her how many languages she spoke; she looked embarrased, then said "five." Then she brightened, and added: "But I'm learning more!"

@Andrzej It was intended to be an unqualified complement. There are many native English speakers in the U.S. who are intimidated by the New York Times crossword, yet you manage both the language and the culture-centric clues.

@Andrzej 

The spider writes "SOME PIG", among other things, to save Wilbur.  A boar is similar to a pig.....

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)

@B 

And my reply finally made it through the E.M.U. gantlet/gauntlet, roughly 8 hours after posting.

Great comment system they've got here.  Time for another article about it.  :(

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(I do this instead of emuing)
@Nancy J.  Re 67A - I was proud of myself for immediately filling in "hangar" until it didn't fit with any crosses. (On Tuesdays, I try to do all the across clues without checking the downs.)

@Caroline Kearney 

That would have been a perfect answer!  Maybe we'll see it someday.

@Rich in Atlanta 
My mom used to get WSJ on Saturdays, and Patrick Berry had some great puzzles, different from x-words. I really liked the Rows Gardens. I wish I could find his puzzles somewhere else - I will not subscribe to WSJ.
@John Carson: Yes. I stared at "SESA good example" for way too long before I realized what it should be.

@Stacey 

They have fixed it, but you have to go into the archives and update the puzzle for it to work. (At least, that’s what you have to do if you opened the puzzle last night.)
@Nancy https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflatable_castle

@Nancy
No names?  There was that Natick at AEGI_ and A_HMAN.  My last letter, and I had to look it up.

@Jesse K 
As I picked up the sheet from my printer, my eyes fell on 21A and I cracked up.
Then DHubby wanted to know what was funny.
So I read the clue to him.  "Who?" he asked.
(DHubs claims to have attended Sunday School in his youth, but this is either a Big Fat Lie or he Never Paid Attention.)

But it was a great clue and entry with which t begin the SOLVE.

@Amy 

For that you have our heartfelt shanks.
@John Carson it was just my poultry attempt at humor. *****ducking*****
@M. Biggen What a lovely thing to say! Thank you!

@Mean Old Lady 

My sister-in-law, whose maiden name was Baldwin, married a guy whose name began with W. 

After they got divorced, she married a guy named Zions. 

Try and top that!
@Mean Old Lady  33 years after i didnt change my name, I still don't understand why women chose to change their names.

@Steve L 

Well, Steve L, I jest cain't.  I'da likedta try, but a gal hasta draw the line somewhere.  Took me 45 years to git *this* fella shaped up, and I'm plum wore out.  Had a look around 9 years ago at the 50th HS Reunion (remembering a handsome classmate name of Yuzna) but he never showed, and nobody knew what became of him.  Oh well.  We are all climbing Jacob's Ladder, but not ever'body can reach Zion{s}.

@mjm 

My simple answer is that I wanted to. I was 35 when I got married, so I didn't feel any pressure that someone younger might have felt and he was fine with whatever I wanted to do, but I just wanted us to have the same last name. 

Could I have talked him into taking my last name? Or joining names? Maybe, but I was happy to take on his. And in keeping with this thread, it moved me much higher in the alphabet! Winning! Haha!  

I will say though, I wasn't ready to lose my original name, so I moved it to my middle name and now have two middle names.

@Mean Old Lady

Sometimes being at the back of the alphabetical line can pay dividends.  My (second) wife’s last initial is also W.  We met in the fourth grade and were always at the back of the line together and had lockers next to each other in high school.  We were never close friends, but because of the curse of the W, we were always aware of each other. After high school we went our separate ways.  Fast forward 36 years and we reconnected, ended up marrying, and just celebrated our 13th anniversary two weeks ago.

@Grant

@Jairus
We can blame ourselves for that idiom.  What are the contents of your teacup?

@Jairus 

I think you misconstrue how the equivalency works.  It's not necessarily a grammatical equivalence between clue and answer ("contents" is plural, so the answer must be plural). 

Here, the clue is a non-count noun phrase.  We  talk about content or contents in general, not one content, two contents.  And the equivalent answer, also non-count, matches the word "mer", a non-count noun in French. The answer, EAU, is also a non-count noun in French.

Hope this helps!
